questions.text: In a study of hypoglycemic shock, cellular changes in the brain are analyzed. One cell type in the hippocampus is noted to exhibit intense cytoplasmic eosinophilia, central chromatolysis, spheroidal swellings, and nuclear pyknosis. These changes appear 12 hours after blood glucose levels drop below 20 mg/dL. What is this cell type most likely to be:
questions.solution:
Explanation:

  • Hypoxic and hypoglycemic injury leads to "red" neurons as the initial reaction. The larger pyramidal neurons are the most sensitive, particularly in the hippocampus with hypoglycemia, as well as neocortical Betz cells and cerebellar Purkinje cells.
  • Astrocytes proliferate in reaction to brain injury in the process called gliosis. Endothelial cells are most likely to proliferate in neoplasms. Microglia respond to brain injury with a macrophage-like function. Oligodendroglial cells provide myelination for brain neuronal axons.

Explanation of Incorrect Options:

Astrocytes (Option A): These glial cells primarily function in supporting neurons, maintaining the blood-brain barrier, and regulating extracellular ion balance. They do not typically undergo acute ischemic or hypoglycemic changes like eosinophilic cytoplasm, nuclear pyknosis, or central chromatolysis. Instead, they react later through hypertrophy and hyperplasia (reactive gliosis).

Endothelial cells (Option B): These cells line cerebral blood vessels and are crucial in maintaining the blood-brain barrier. They are not the primary cells to undergo morphological injury in hypoglycemia. Damage to endothelial cells occurs more in conditions such as ischemic stroke, trauma, or inflammatory processes, rather than hypoglycemia-induced neuronal death.

Microglia (Option C): These are the resident macrophages of the CNS and act as immune surveillance cells. In hypoglycemia, microglia are activated secondarily in response to neuronal injury, where they phagocytose necrotic debris. They are not the first cells to show the cytoplasmic eosinophilia, spheroidal swellings, or pyknosis described in the vignette.

questions.text: A female neonate is noted at birth to have a gross deformity of her lower back. Examination of the subcutaneous lesion reveals disorganized neural tissue with entrapment of nerve roots. What is the appropriate diagnosis?
questions.solution:
Explanation:

  • Neural tube defects (dysraphic anomalies) reflect impaired closure of the dorsal aspect of the vertebral column.Meningomyelocele exposes the spinal canal and causes the nerve roots to be entrapped.
  • These abnormalities are classified according to the extent of the defect, ranging in severity from spina bifida occulta to meningocele, meningomyelocele, and rachischisis.
  • Spina bifida occulta (Option D ruled out) is restricted to the vertebral arches and is usually asymptomatic.
  • Meningocele (Option A ruled out) permits protrusion of the meninges as a fluid-filled sac.
  • Rachischisis (Option C ruled out) is an extreme defect, often without a recognizable spinal cord.

Explanation of Incorrect Options:

Meningocele (Option A): This defect involves protrusion of meninges filled with CSF through a vertebral defect, but without neural tissue inside the sac. Since the vignette clearly mentions disorganized neural tissue with entrapment of nerve roots, this excludes meningocele.

Rachischisis (Option C): This is the most severe form of neural tube defect where the neural tissue is exposed on the surface without any covering by skin or meninges. The case describes a subcutaneous lesion with entrapped nerve roots, indicating some covering is present, hence not rachischisis.

Spina bifida occulta (Option D): This is a mild defect in which vertebral arches fail to fuse, but there is no herniation of meninges or neural tissue. It often presents only with a skin marker like a tuft of hair or dimple. Since this neonate has a gross deformity with neural tissue protrusion, it cannot be spina bifida occulta.

questions.text: An 18-year-old man suffers massive trauma in a motorcycle accident. A CT scan shows multiple intracerebral hemorrhages. The patient expires after 6 months in a coma. At autopsy, there are cystic cavities within the frontal and temporal lobes, corresponding to the areas of prior hemorrhage. These cavities were formed in large measure due to the phagocytic activity of which of the following cell types?
questions.solution:
Explanation:

  • Microglia are phagocytic macrophage-derived cells of the CNS, accounting for 5% of all glial cells. In response to necrosis, macroglia become phagocytic, accumulate lipids and other cellular debris, and are designated gitter cells. Some reactive microglia exhibit a prominent elongated nucleus, in which case they are referred to as rod cells.
  • After microglial phagocytosis, astrocytosis (choice a) then leads to local scar formation, which persists as telltale evidence of a prior injury.

Explanation of Incorrect Options:

Astrocytes (Option A): These glial cells provide structural and metabolic support to neurons and form glial scars after CNS injury. While they proliferate in response to damage (gliosis), they are not the main phagocytic cells clearing necrotic tissue and blood breakdown products.

Endothelial cells (Option B): These line cerebral blood vessels and maintain the blood-brain barrier. They may become damaged in trauma or hemorrhage, but they do not play a role in phagocytosis of necrotic debris or formation of cystic cavities.

Neutrophils (Option D): These are the first responders in acute inflammation, infiltrating within hours after injury. However, their role is short-lived and limited to acute necrotic tissue clearance. They do not persist to form the cystic cavities seen months later; that role belongs to resident CNS phagocytes (microglia).

questions.text: A 55-year-old man suddenly loses consciousness while driving his truck, but he is traveling at a slow speed and comes to a stop without a collision. Paramedics arrive but are unable to arouse him. On physical examination, there is bilateral papilledema. He has no spontaneous movements. The figure shows the gross appearance of the brain at autopsy. Which underlying condition is most likely to have resulted in this lesion?
questions.solution:
Explanation:

  • Hypertensive hemorrhages are most likely to arise in the basal ganglia (shown in the figure), thalamus, cerebral white matter, pons, or cerebellum. Multiple hemorrhages are uncommon.
  • The small vessels weakened by hyaline arteriolosclerosis are prone to rupture.

Explanation of other options:

  • Chronic alcoholism(Option A): It predisposes to falls with subdural hematomas or contusions.
  • Metastatic carcinoma (Option B): Metastases are typically multiple and peripheral at the gray white junction.
  • Multiple sclerosis (Option C): The plaques of multiple sclerosis occur in white matter and do not bleed.

questions.text: Increased vascular permeability due to inflammation or in tumors is called
questions.solution:
Explanation:

  • Cytotoxic edema is an increase in intracellular fluid secondary to neuronal and glial cell injury.
  • Hydrocephalus refers to an increase in the volume of the CSF within the ventricular system.
  • Herniation is the displacement of brain tissue from one compartment to another in response to increased intracranial pressure.
  • Vasogenic edema is defined as extracellular accumulation of fluid resulting from disruption of the blood-brain barrier (bbb) and extravasations of serum proteins.

Explanation of Incorrect Options:

Cytotoxic edema (Option B): This type of edema results from cellular injury (e.g., hypoxia, ischemia, or toxins), leading to failure of ATP-dependent ion pumps. Sodium and water accumulate inside neurons and glial cells, causing intracellular swelling. It is not related to increased vascular permeability.

Herniation (Option C): This refers to displacement of brain tissue due to increased intracranial pressure, such as transtentorial or tonsillar herniation. It is a complication of severe edema or mass lesions, but not a form of edema itself.

Hydrocephalus (Option D): This is the abnormal accumulation of cerebrospinal fluid (CSF) within the ventricular system, either due to obstruction, poor absorption, or increased production. It is distinct from edema and not caused by vascular permeability changes.

questions.text: Which cell of the brain produces myelin?
questions.solution:
Explanation:

  • Oligodendrocytes, which produce myelin, exhibit a limited spectrum of specific morphologic changes in response to various injuries.
  • In progressive multifocal leukoencephalopathy, viral inclusions can be seen in oligodendrocytes, with a smudgy, homogeneous-appearing enlarged nucleus.

Explanation of Incorrect Options:

Astrocytes (Option A): These cells provide structural and metabolic support to neurons, regulate the blood-brain barrier, and maintain extracellular ion balance. They do not produce myelin.

Microglia (Option C): These are the resident macrophages of the CNS, responsible for immune defense and phagocytosis of cellular debris. They are not involved in myelination.

Ependymal cells (Option D): These line the ventricles of the brain and the central canal of the spinal cord. Their main function is to help in the production and circulation of cerebrospinal fluid (CSF), not myelin formation.

questions.text: Which cell is principally responsible for repair and scar formation in the brain?
questions.solution:
Explanation:

  • Astrocyte Injury and Repair. Astrocytes are the principal cells responsible for repair and scar formation in the brain, a process termed gliosis.
  • In response to injury, astrocytes undergo both hypertrophy and hyperplasia. The nucleus enlarges and becomes vesicular, and the nucleolus becomes prominent. The cytoplasm expands and takes on a bright pink hue, and the cell extends multiple stout, ramifying processes called gemistocytic astrocytes.

Explanation of Incorrect Options:

Oligodendrocytes (Option B): These cells are responsible for producing and maintaining myelin in the central nervous system. They play no role in scar formation or tissue repair after injury.

Microglia (Option C): These are the resident macrophages of the CNS. Their role in injury is primarily phagocytosis of necrotic debris and immune defense, not scar formation.

Ependymal cells (Option D): These line the ventricular system and central canal of the spinal cord, aiding in cerebrospinal fluid (CSF) production and circulation. They do not participate in tissue repair or gliosis.

questions.text: A 50-year-old man presents with a "staggering" gait and "lightning pain" in his hands and legs. His past medical history is significant for an aortic aneurysm and aortic insufficiency. Neurologic examination reveals impaired senses of vibration, as well as touch and pain in the lower extremities. The patient subsequently dies of pneumonia. Autopsy discloses obliterative endarteritis of meningeal blood vessels and atrophy of the posterior columns of the spinal cord. What is the appropriate diagnosis?
questions.solution:
Explanation:

  • Tabes dorsalis is a feature of tertiary syphilis and is characterized by chronic fibrosing meningitis, which constricts the posterior root of the spinal cord.
  • The posterior roots contain sensory nerves that originate in the spinal ganglia and form the posterior columns of the spinal cord.
  • Compression of sensory nerves that originate in the posterior roots causes lancinating pain in extremities. It also damages the transmission of proprioceptive impulses, causing gait disturbances (ataxia).

Explanation of other options:

  • Amyotrophic lateral sclerosis (Option A): It is a motor neuron disease that does not affect the posterior columns.
  • Friedreich ataxia (Option B): It is an autosomal dominant trait that involves the spinal cord in a complex way.
  • Huntington disease (Option C): It affects not only the centripetal pathways (spinocerebellar and posterior columns), but also the efferent corticospinal tracts.

questions.text: A 5-year-old boy is brought to the emergency room with fever, vomiting, and convulsions. The patient is febrile to 39.5°C (104°F). Physical examination reveals cervical rigidity and pain in the neck and knees. Acute inflammation most likely involves which anatomic region of the patient's brain?
questions.solution:
Explanation:

  • Meningitis is a dangerous infection caused by a variety of microorganisms. Leptomeningitis denotes an inflammatory process localized to the pia/arachnoid. This compartment houses the CSF, an excellent culture medium for most microorganisms. With few exceptions, all forms of meningitis are initiated by microorganisms, suppurative bacteria being the principal offenders. In untreated cases, delirium gives way to coma and death. The other choices are rarely affected by bacteria.

Explanation of Incorrect Options:

Choroid plexus (Option A): The choroid plexus produces cerebrospinal fluid (CSF) and serves as a barrier between blood and CSF. It is not the primary site of acute inflammation in meningitis.

Ependyma (Option B): These are the epithelial cells lining the ventricles of the brain and central canal of the spinal cord. They are not directly involved in the inflammatory process of meningitis.

Lateral ventricles (Option C): These are CSF-filled cavities within the cerebral hemispheres. They may become secondarily involved (e.g., ventriculitis) but are not the site of primary inflammation in meningitis.

questions.text: A 42-year-old man with AIDS dementia complex dies of respiratory insufficiency secondary to Pneumocystis carinii pneumonia. Examination of the brain at autopsy reveals mild cerebral atrophy, with dilation of the lateral ventricles. Which of the cells are the main culprit for the neuropathologic changes?
questions.solution:
Explanation:

  • In most patients with AIDS encephalopathy, the disease is attributable to an active infection of the CNS by the virus itself. Macrophages and microglial cells in the CNS are productively infected by HIV-1. Although neurons and astrocytes may interact with the virus, they do not seem to be infected but are injured indirectly by cytokines or other neurotoxic factors released by macrophages.
  • Also only microglia cells express both CD 4 co-receptor and chemokines receptors (CCR5 and CXCR4) that are required in combination for efficient infection by HIV.

Explanation of Incorrect Options:

Astrocyte (Option A): These cells provide metabolic and structural support to neurons and contribute to repair by forming glial scars. They are not the primary mediators of the neuropathologic damage in AIDS dementia complex.

Oligodendrocytes (Option B): These cells are responsible for CNS myelination. Their injury causes demyelinating diseases (e.g., multiple sclerosis), but they are not the main cells driving HIV-related brain damage.

Ependymal (Option D): These line the ventricles and central canal, playing a role in CSF production and circulation. They are not significantly involved in the pathogenesis of HIV encephalopathy.

questions.text: A 52-year-old man is brought to the emergency room 2 hours after being involved in an automobile accident. The patient denies striking his head, although his head was thrust forward and backward. His vital signs are normal, and he returns home. The following day, the patient's wife notices that he is lethargic. By the time the ambulance arrives at the emergency room, the patient is comatose. Which of the following is the most likely cause of the decline in mental status in this patient?
questions.solution:
Explanation:

  • The consequences of traumatic brain injury may be internal and subtle. The parasagittal cortex is anchored to arachnoid villi, whereas the lateral aspects of the cerebrum move more freely.
  • This anatomical feature, together with the differential density of gray and white matter, permits generation of shearing forces between different brain regions, leading to diffuse axonal shearing injuries, particularly in vehicular accidents.
  • Shearing injuries can distort or disrupt axons, causing them to retract into "spheroids", as well as lose myelin. This type of injury typically occurs in parasagittal white matter and may be accompanied by multiple small hemorrhages. Duret hemorrhage (choice b) occurs in the uncus during transtentorial herniation.

Explanation of Incorrect Options:

Duret hemorrhages (Option B): These are small linear or flame-shaped hemorrhages in the midline of the midbrain and pons, typically caused by downward transtentorial herniation. They are not the result of acceleration-deceleration trauma as in this case.

Ruptured saccular aneurysm (Option C): This typically presents with sudden, severe "worst headache of life" due to subarachnoid hemorrhage. It is unrelated to trauma and does not match the delayed coma after whiplash-type injury described here.

Spinal cord contusions (Option D): These occur from direct trauma to the spinal cord, leading to motor and sensory deficits below the level of injury. They would not explain the progressive decline in mental status or coma in this patient.

questions.text: A 12-year-old boy develops fever, accompanied by occasional headaches, malaise, fatigue, and nausea a month after being bitten by a dog. One day later, he experiences episodes of rigidity, hallucinations, breath holding, and difficulty swallowing because of uncontrollable oral secretions. Neurologists were consulted and immediately treatment started with some injectable medicines. Which of the pathological findings is the hallmark of the disease?
questions.solution:
Explanation:

  • The child had rabies, an infectious disease in which the virus travels from the site of an infected animal bite up nerves to the CNS.
  • Pathognomonic Negri bodies are cytoplasmic inclusions found in the hippocampal pyramidal cells and cerebellar Purkinje cells.

Explanation of Incorrect Options:

Perivascular lymphocytes (Option B): This pattern is more typical of viral encephalitides in general (e.g., arboviruses, measles), where lymphocytic infiltrates are seen around blood vessels. It is not the specific hallmark of rabies.

Pseudocysts with bradyzoites (Option C): These are characteristic of Toxoplasma gondii infection, often affecting immunocompromised patients. They are unrelated to rabies virus infection.

Spongiform change (Option D): This refers to vacuolation of neurons and neuropil, a hallmark of prion diseases (e.g., Creutzfeldt-Jakob disease), not rabies.

questions.text: A 60-year-old woman had problems related to movement for 5 years. Physical examination showed cogwheel rigidity of limbs and a festinating gait, which she had difficulty initiating. Her face was expressionless. She was given levodopa/carbidopa, and her condition improved. Two years later, she had difficulty performing activities of daily living and showed marked cognitive decline. She died of aspiration pneumonia. Autopsy findings include mild cerebral atrophy and loss of substantia nigra pigmentation. Microscopically, cortical neurons show spheroidal, intraneuronal, cytoplasmic, and eosinophilic inclusions. Immunohisto chemical staining for which of the following proteins is most likely to be positive in these inclusions?
questions.solution:
Explanation:

  • Dementia with Lewy bodies (DLB) combines clinical features of Alzheimer disease (AD) and idiopathic Parkinson disease. Mutations in the gene for α-synuclein have been linked to idiopathic Parkinson disease, and Lewy bodies can be found in the substantia nigra neurons, but the clinical dementia and cortical Lewy bodies point to DLB.
  • Amyloid precursor protein (APP) is encoded by a gene on chromosome 21 (perhaps explaining early AD in trisomy 21) and is processed to form the Aβ amyloid of neuritic plaques in AD.
  • The e4 allele of apolipoprotein E can bind Aβ and increase the risk of AD. Huntingtin is the protein product of the HD gene in Huntington disease.
  • Presenilin 1 and 2 mutations can increase production of Aβ and increase the risk of early-onset AD. Tau protein is found in neurofibrillary tangles of AD and in Pick bodies of Pick disease.

Explanation of Incorrect Options:

Amyloid precursor protein (Option B): This protein is associated with Alzheimer's disease, where abnormal cleavage produces β-amyloid plaques. It is not a component of Lewy bodies, which are the hallmark inclusions in Parkinson's disease and dementia with Lewy bodies.

Apolipoprotein E (Option C): ApoE (especially the ε4 allele) is a genetic risk factor for Alzheimer's disease and influences amyloid deposition. It does not localize to Lewy bodies and is not the relevant marker in this case.

Huntingtin (Option D): This abnormal protein, due to CAG trinucleotide repeat expansion, causes Huntington's disease, characterized by caudate atrophy and choreiform movements. It is unrelated to the pathology of Parkinson's disease or dementia with Lewy bodies.

questions.text: A 63-year-old man presents with a 2-week history of tonic-clonic seizures that initially involve his left arm but have more recently progressed to involve his left leg. The seizures are accompanied by muscle weakness but no other neurologic signs. The cranial nerves are intact, and the Babinski sign is present. A CT scan reveals a mass in the left cerebral hemisphere. A left frontoparietal craniotomy is performed. Histologic examination of the brain biopsy is shown in the image. Which of the following is the appropriate diagnosis?
questions.solution:
Explanation:

  • Glioblastoma is a brain tumor composed of malignant astroglial cells, which show marked pleomorphism and are often Because of their invasive properties and vascular changes ("arteritic obliteration"), the tumors feature patchy yellow areas of necrosis and red zones of hemorrhage.
  • The term multiforme derives from the variegated gross appearance of these tumors and the histologic pleomorphism of the tumor cells.
  • The other choices do not display the characteristic palisading of tumor cells around necrotic areas (see photomicrograph).

Explanation of Incorrect Options:

Craniopharyngioma (Option A): This tumor arises from Rathke's pouch remnants and is typically located in the suprasellar region, often affecting children or young adults. It causes visual disturbances and endocrine abnormalities, not seizures from a cortical lesion in the frontoparietal region.

Ependymoma (Option B): This tumor arises from ependymal cells lining the ventricles or central canal of the spinal cord. In children, it commonly occurs in the fourth ventricle, producing hydrocephalus. Cortical seizures and frontoparietal lesions are not characteristic.

Ganglioglioma (Option C): This rare, low-grade tumor contains both mature neurons and glial elements. It often presents in young patients with long-standing epilepsy rather than a rapidly progressive course in an older adult. The histology in glioblastoma shows pleomorphic cells, necrosis, and pseudopalisading-features not seen in ganglioglioma.

questions.text: A 10-year-old male child presented with a persistent headache, associated with nausea and vomiting some times. CT scan of the head shows well demarcated oval shaped lesions with cystic change having smooth margin in the cerebellar region. Craniotomy was done, a small part of the lesion is removed and sent for histopathological examination, the image of which is shown below. Based on the above findings, what is your probable diagnosis?
questions.solution:
Explanation:

  • Cerebellar pilocytic astrocytomas usually present during the first two decades of life, with clumsiness, worsening headache, nausea, and vomiting. Most cerebellar and cerebral pilocytic astrocytomas are well demarcated, with a round or oval shape and smooth margins.
  • Calcifications are occasionally present. Heterogeneity as a result of cyst-like areas intermixed with generally intensely enhancing soft tissue components is typical.
  • On microscopy an astrocytic tumor of low to moderate cellularity often has a biphasic pattern, with varying proportions of compacted bipolar cells with rosenthal fibers and loose-textured multipolar cells with microcysts. The biphasic pattern is best seen in cerebellar tumors.

Explanation of Incorrect Options:

Glioblastoma (Option A): This is a highly malignant astrocytic tumor typically seen in adults, most often located in the cerebral hemispheres. It is characterized by marked pleomorphism, pseudopalisading necrosis, and microvascular proliferation. It is not well-demarcated and cystic with smooth margins in the cerebellum of a child.

Medulloblastoma (Option B): This malignant embryonal tumor occurs in the cerebellum of children but typically arises in the midline (vermis). It appears solid, highly cellular, and invasive rather than well-circumscribed and cystic. It also commonly causes obstructive hydrocephalus and is more aggressive compared to pilocytic astrocytoma.

Ependymoma (Option D): This tumor arises from ependymal cells and usually occurs near or within the fourth ventricle, often leading to hydrocephalus. Histology shows perivascular pseudorosettes. The described lesion in the cerebellar hemisphere with cystic change and smooth margins is not typical of ependymoma.

questions.text:
A 44-year-old male patient presented with headaches, with occasional change in behavior. There is an occurrence of seizure infrequently. CT scan performed shows isodense well demarcated mass lesion located in cortex with perifocal edema. Craniotomy was done and tissue removed sent for histopathological examination, the images of which are attached below.

What is your probable diagnosis?
questions.solution:
Explanation:

  • Oligodendrogliomas arise preferentially in the white matter and cortex of the cerebral hemispheres. The frontal lobe is the most common location (involved in >50% of all patients).
  • Clinical Presentation
    • Seizures are the most common presenting symptom, seen in approximately two-thirds of patients
  • Other presenting features include:
    • Headache
    • Signs of increased intracranial pressure
    • Focal neurological deficits
    • Cognitive or mental changes
  • Imaging Characteristics,CT Scan Findings:
    • Lesions appear in hypodense or isodense.
    • Typically seen as a well-demarcated mass.
    • Commonly located in the cortex and subcortical white matter.
    • Calcifications are frequently observed (though not diagnostic).
    • Generally exhibits little perifocal edema.
  • Histopathological Features
    • Oligodendrogliomas are diffusely infiltrating gliomas of moderate cellularity.
  • Cellular Morphology:
    • Composed of monomorphic cells with Uniform round nuclei
    • Perinuclear haloes (especially on paraffin sections)
    • Classic appearance described as "honeycomb" or "fried egg".
  • Additional features include microcalcifications, mucoid/ cystic degeneration, and a dense network of delicate branching capillaries. Mitotic activity is either absent or low.

Explanation of Incorrect Options:

Pilocytic astrocytoma (Option A): This is a benign, cystic astrocytic tumor, most common in children and usually located in the cerebellum. It is rare in adults and does not typically present as a well-demarcated cortical lesion with seizures.

Glioblastoma (Option B): This is a highly malignant astrocytic tumor, usually poorly circumscribed, with features such as pseudopalisading necrosis and vascular proliferation. It tends to present with rapidly progressive neurological deficits rather than infrequent seizures and is not usually well demarcated on imaging.

Ependymoma (Option D): This tumor arises from ependymal cells lining the ventricles or central canal of the spinal cord. It often occurs in children in the posterior fossa, or in the spinal cord in adults. A cortical, well-demarcated lesion with calcification and seizures is not characteristic of ependymoma.

questions.text: A 23-year-old male patient presented with a persistent headache associated with nausea and vomiting. On clinical examination it is found to have raised intracranial pressure due to lesion in posterior fossa. On gadolinium enhanced MRI shows well circumscribed mass with mild enhancement. After craniotomy tissue is taken for diagnosis and sent for histopathological examination, image of which is shown below. What is your probable diagnosis?
questions.solution:
Explanation for answer:

  • Ependymomas can develop in patients of any age, with reported patient ages ranging from birth to 81 years. Ependymomas may occur along the ventricular system or spinal canal, in the cerebral hemispheres, or at extra CNS sites
  • Location: Can develop anywhere along the ventricular system or spinal canal. May also occur in the cerebral hemispheres or extra-CNS sites.
  • Distribution:
    • 60% arise in the posterior fossa.
    • 30% occur in the supratentorial compartment.
  • Clinical Manifestations: Dependent on tumor location.
    • Posterior fossa tumors typically present with:
      • Signs of hydrocephalus.
    • Raised intracranial pressure symptoms:
      • Headache
      • Nausea
      • Vomiting
      • Dizziness
    • Imaging Features (Gadolinium-enhanced MRI)
      • Shows well-circumscribed masses.
      • Variable degrees of contrast enhancement.
    • Often associated with:
      • Ventricular obstruction
      • Brainstem displacement
      • Hydrocephalus
      • Histological Features
  • Classic ependymoma is a well-delineated glioma with monomorphic cells characterized by a variable density and round to oval nuclei with speckled nuclear chromatin. The key histological features are perivascular anucleate zones (pseudorosettes) and (true) ependymal rosettes.
  • Key microscopic features:
    • Perivascular pseudorosettes:
      • Tumor cells radially arranged around blood vessels.
      • Surrounding anucleate fibrillary zones.
    • True ependymal rosettes and tubular canals:
      • Cuboidal or columnar tumor cells.
      • Arranged around a central lumen.

Explanation of Incorrect Options:

Pilocytic astrocytoma (Option A): This typically occurs in children and young adults, most commonly in the cerebellum. It usually appears as a cystic lesion with an enhancing mural nodule and contains Rosenthal fibers histologically. The case describes a solid posterior fossa mass with mild enhancement, which is more consistent with ependymoma.

Glioblastoma (Option B): This is a highly aggressive astrocytic tumor that usually arises in the cerebral hemispheres of older adults. It presents as an ill-defined, infiltrative, and heterogeneously enhancing lesion with necrosis and hemorrhage. It is uncommon in the posterior fossa and in young adults.

Oligodendroglioma (Option C): This tumor most often occurs in the cerebral hemispheres (particularly frontal lobe) of adults. It is associated with calcifications and a "fried-egg" appearance histologically. It is not a posterior fossa tumor and does not match the imaging findings in this case.

choices.text: It can be solid and cystic
It is biphasic tumor shows microcystic and fibrillary area
Rosenthal fiber and eosinophilic granular bodies

questions.text: A 5-year-old patient presented with unconsciousness and projectile vomiting. MRI brain shows lesion in cerebellum and characteristic histological diagram is shown below. All of the following are true; except:
questions.solution:
Explanation:

  • Unconsciousness and projectile vomiting are suggestive of raised intracranial tension. Since the mass is in cerebellum, and biopsy shows the eosinophilic granular body and Rosenthal fibers, it is suggestive of Pilocytic astrocytoma. Pseudopalisading is a feature of Glioblastoma multiforme.

Explanation of Incorrect Options:

It can be solid and cystic (Option A): Pilocytic astrocytoma, the most common cerebellar tumor in children, often presents as a cystic lesion with an enhancing mural nodule, though it can also have solid components. This is true.

It is biphasic tumor shows microcystic and fibrillary area (Option B): Histologically, pilocytic astrocytoma is biphasic, with alternating loose microcystic areas and compact fibrillary regions. This is also correct.

Rosenthal fiber and eosinophilic granular bodies (Option C): These are hallmark microscopic features of pilocytic astrocytoma and help distinguish it from more aggressive gliomas. This statement is correct.

questions.text: A patient presented with painless proptosis. Biopsy from the orbital mass showed the following image?
questions.solution:
Explanation:

  • The image shows tumor cells arranged in palisading (Verocay body) and you can see the cellular areas Antoni A and acellular areas Antoni B. This is seen in Schwannoma.

Explanation of Incorrect Options:

Neurofibroma (Option A): This tumor arises from peripheral nerve elements but is composed of a mixture of Schwann cells, fibroblasts, and perineural cells. Unlike schwannoma, it is not encapsulated and tends to infiltrate the nerve. Histology does not show the classic Antoni A/B areas or Verocay bodies typical of schwannoma.

Rhabdomyoma (Option B): This is a rare benign tumor of striated muscle, most often seen in the heart or head and neck region. It does not arise in the orbit or from peripheral nerves, and histology is entirely different (shows large polygonal cells with cross striations).

Leiomyoma (Option C): This benign tumor of smooth muscle most often occurs in the uterus, GI tract, or skin. Orbital presentation is extremely rare, and histology shows spindle cells with cigar-shaped nuclei-not Antoni A/B patterns.

questions.text: A 10-year-old child with posterior fossa mass. On biopsy the following features were seen. What are these dense eosinophilic fibers marked with an arrow?
questions.solution:
Explanation:

  • Rosenthal fibers are eosinophilic, corkscrew fibers found in pilocytic astrocytoma, the most common primary brain tumor in children. They contain two heat-shock proteins (αB-crystallin and hsp27) as well as ubiquitin.
  • They are seen in Alexander disease and pilocytic astrocytoma.

Explanation of Incorrect Options:

The Alzheimer type II astrocyte (Option B): These are abnormal astrocytes with large, clear nuclei and minimal cytoplasm, typically seen in hepatic encephalopathy due to hyperammonemia. They are not dense eosinophilic fibers and are not related to pilocytic astrocytoma.

Corpora amylacea (Option C): These are basophilic, round, laminated, glycoprotein-rich inclusions found in astrocytic processes, usually in aging brains. They are not elongated, eosinophilic fibers and do not appear in childhood posterior fossa tumors.

None of the above (Option D): Incorrect because the described structures are classic for Rosenthal fibers, so a definitive answer exists.

questions.text: A full-term newborn presents with a large, cystic, midline swelling in the lumbosacral region, as shown in the image below. The swelling is translucent, dome-shaped, and has visible vascular markings. What is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
Explanation:

  • The lumbar region of a newborn baby with myelomeningocele. The skin is intact, and the placode-containing remnants of nervous tissue can be observed in the center of the lesion, which is filled with cerebrospinal fluid.
  • It is the most common form of open spina bifida.
  • Spina bifida (Option C) is a general term that includes spina bifida occulta, meningocele, and meningomyelocele.

Explanation of Incorrect Options:

Myelocele (Option A): In myelocele, the neural tissue is exposed at the surface and lies flush with the skin, without a cystic, dome-shaped translucent swelling. This does not match the described lesion.

Spina bifida (Option C): This is a broad term describing defective closure of the vertebral arches. The mildest form, spina bifida occulta, presents only with a tuft of hair or dimple and no cystic swelling. The case here shows a large cystic lesion with visible vascular markings, making spina bifida alone an incomplete diagnosis.

None of the above (Option D): Incorrect, because the description exactly matches a defined entity-lumbar meningomyelocele.

questions.text: A 40-year-old male died following a short illness characterized by high fever and altered sensorium. Autopsy reveals the brain section shown in the image below. What is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
Explanation:

  • The image shows a well-circumscribed lesion in the brain with a central area of necrosis surrounded by a distinct rim.This appearance is classic for a cerebral abscess.
  • The central necrotic area typically contains pus, surrounded by reactive gliosis and fibrosis.
  • Cerebral abscess usually follows bacterial infections, either from hematogenous spread, contiguous sinus/mastoid infections, or trauma.
  • Clinically associated with fever, headache, neurological deficits, and sometimes seizures.
  • Gross pathology shows central liquefactive necrosis (pus) with a surrounding capsule, as seen in the image.

Explanation of other options:

  • Cerebral Infarction(Option B):Infarcts appear wedge-shaped, poorly demarcated early on, and typically affect vascular territories.Over time, infarcts undergo softening and later cystic changes, but they do not have the distinct ring-enhancing or capsule-like appearance of an abscess.
  • Cerebral Tumor(Option C):Tumors are usually solid, infiltrative, and may or may not show necrosis. Some high-grade gliomas can mimic abscesses radiologically but are not typically associated with fever and acute systemic symptoms. Histopathology is needed for definitive diagnosis.

questions.text: Identify the Rosette and Diagnosis.
questions.solution:
Explanation:

  • In this pattern, a spoke-wheel arrangement of cells with tapered cellular processes radiates around a wall of a centrally placed vessel.
  • Seen in

Explanation of Incorrect Options:

Homer-Wright rosette (Option B): These are circular arrangements of tumor cells around a central tangle of fibrillary processes (neuropil), without a true lumen or blood vessel. They are classically seen in medulloblastoma, neuroblastoma, and primitive neuroectodermal tumors, not in ependymoma.

True rosette (Option C): In this pattern, tumor cells form a circular arrangement around an empty lumen. These are uncommon and can be seen in some embryonal tumors. They are not the characteristic feature of ependymomas.

Flexner-Wintersteiner rosette (Option D): These consist of tumor cells surrounding a central lumen that mimics the embryonal retina, and are classically seen in retinoblastoma. They are not found in posterior fossa ependymomas.

questions.text: A 5-year-old child with posterior fossa mass. Biopsy from the mass shows the following rosettes.
questions.solution:
Explanation:

  • Type of pseudo rosette in which differentiated tumor cells surround the neuropil seen in neuroblastoma, medulloblastoma, pinealoblastoma.

Explanation of Incorrect Options:

Perivascular pseudorosette (Option B): In this pattern, tumor cells are radially arranged around a blood vessel with intervening processes of fibrillary material. This is characteristic of ependymoma, not medulloblastoma.

Flexner-Wintersteiner rosette (Option C): These have tumor cells arranged around a central lumen resembling photoreceptor differentiation, and are seen in retinoblastoma. They are not found in medulloblastoma.

None of the above (Option D): Incorrect, because the described rosettes in a posterior fossa tumor of a child are specifically Homer-Wright rosettes.
